chapter.title: The RESTful Security Token Service (REST-STS)
chapter.para: This chapter specifies the configuration requirements associated with the RESTful Security Token Service (REST-STS). Like previous implementations of STS, this implementation secures identity tokens and messages.
REST-STS is inspired by WS-Trust STS. REST-STS supports one basic operation: token transformation. This chapter describes how you can configure REST-STS token transformations by using the OpenAM UI.

Different Identity Relationship Management (IRM) services may provide differing token types. Given the variety of token types in use today, it can be helpful to have a service that you can configure to transform tokens.

section.title: About REST-STS

note.para: Do not use the WSP and WSC agent UI tools described in Configuring Policy Agent Profiles.

section.para: The OpenAM implementation of REST-STS supports a variety of token transformations, as well as different attributes from SAML2 assertions, along with different encryption contexts.
REST-STS supports transformations from the following types of tokens:

listitem.para: UNT: Username Tokens. A tuple of username and password.
OpenID Connect: OpenID Connect tokens.
OpenAM: OpenAM session tokens.
X.509: X.509 tokens.

section.para: At this time, the ForgeRock REST-STS supports conversions from these types of tokens to a SAML2 token. For the conversion, you can configure OpenAM to invalidate the interim OpenAM session.

section.title: Configuring the Security Token Service
section.para: To access the REST-STS configuration menu for your realm, navigate to Access Control > Realm Name > STS. When you see the Realm Name - REST STS Instances menu, click Add. You should see an excerpt of the REST Security Token Service menu in the following screen shot.

mediaobject.alt: The REST Security Token Service UI

textobject.para: You can configure the REST STS from this realm-based menu

section.para: The REST STS configuration menu is subdivided into three sections:

section.title: General Configuration
section.para: At the top of the REST STS configuration menu, you can set up the General Configuration for the system.
You will first add a name for the REST-STS token issuer. You can pick any name; REST-STS includes that name with the issuer label for each token.
You can then select from the supported types of token transformations. Be aware, you should not select both "invalidate" and "don't invalidate" options for the same token transformation.

section.title: Deployment Configuration
section.para: In the Deployment Configuration section, you can assign a specific endpoint for the REST STS, and set up the mapping for each token transformation.

OpenAM includes what you enter in the Deployment Url Element text box in the REST-STS endpoint, as well as the name of the REST-STS instance. As an example, assume that you've set the Deployment Url Element to instance1, on a realm named NewRealm.
In that case, the STS Endpoint URI would be rest-sts/NewRealm/instance1, and the REST STS Instance would be NewRealm/instance1.

Under Authentication Target Mappings, you can configure two or three pieces of information related to each input token. The default options shown in this field are known as a tuple, an ordered list of elements. Each element is separated with a pipe character: "|".

listitem.para: Whether the target is a module or service

varlistentry.term: Name of the authentication module or service

listitem.para: Two default options are included: the ldapService service for usernames, and OPENIDCONNECT module to identify elements of the OpenAM RESTful authentication context that should be consumed to validate that OpenID Connect token.
The OPENIDCONNECT module supports the transformation of a token from OpenID Connect to SAML2.
Defines STS authentication context information about the token to be consumed. In the case shown in the default, the name of the token to be consumed is oidc_id_token.

section.para: Additional deployment configuration options are as follows:

listitem.para: Token transformations which take X509 Certificates as the input token require that the X509 Certficate be presented by using two-way TLS, so that the TLS handshake can validate client certificate ownership.

A standard means of obtaining the client certificate presented via two-way TLS is by using the javax.servlet.request.X509Certificate attribute in the ServletRequest. However, in TLS-offloaded deployments, the TLS-offloader must communicate the client certificate to its ultimate destination by using an HTTP header.

When configuring a REST-STS instance that is to support token transformations with X509 Certificate input, and OpenAM is deployed in a TLS-offloaded context, set this value to the header value which the TLS-offloading engine will use to set client certificates presented by using the TLS handshake.
Specify a list of IP addresses of TLS-offload engines from which to accept client certificates from.

section.title: Issued SAML2 Token Configuration
section.para: This REST-STS configuration UI supports token transformations from username, Open ID Connect, OpenAM, and x509 tokens to SAML2 format. Configure the options shown in this part of the REST-STS UI menu to customize how OpenAM will create those SAML2 tokens.
Several options require you to include the specific classes, either in a custom .jar file or classes configured in files in the WEB-INF/classes directory.

listitem.para: Enter an audience attribute value to populate the AudienceRestriction element of the Conditions element.

note.para: This value is required when issuing Bearer assertions.

listitem.para: For more information, see section 4.1.4.2 of http://docs.oasis-open.org/security/saml/v2.0/saml-profiles-2.0-os.pdf.

varlistentry.term: Service Provider Assertion Consumer Service Url

listitem.para: Enter a recipient attribute value to populate the SubjectConfirmation element.

note.para: This value is required when issuing Bearer assertions.

listitem.para: For more information, see section 4.1.4.2 of http://docs.oasis-open.org/security/saml/v2.0/saml-profiles-2.0-os.pdf.
Specify the name identifier format for the SAML2 token that you want REST-STS to generate.
Enter the desired lifetime for the SAML2 token that you want REST-STS to generate. The default is 10 minutes.
If you need to customize the conditions for the issued SAML2 token, specify the class name of the implementation in the associated text box.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.ConditionsProvider interface.
If you need to define a custom provider for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the provider here.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.SubjectProvider interface.
If you need to create a custom authentication statement for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the statement here.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.AuthenticationStatementsProvider interface.
If you need to define a custom attribute statement for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the statement here.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.AttributeStatementsProvider interface.

varlistentry.term: Custom Authorization Decision Statements Class Name (optional)

listitem.para: If you need to set up a custom authorization decision statement for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the statement here.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.AuthzDecisionStatementsProvider interface.
If you need to define a custom attribute mapper for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the mapper here.
Implement the specified class name with the org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.AttributeMapper interface.
If you need to note a custom AuthContext mapper for the SAML2 token, enter the class name of the context here.

If you need to include an AuthnContext mapping, implemented by the org.forgerock.openam.sts.token.provider.AuthnContextMapperImpl class, enter the class name of the following interface: org.forgerock.openam.sts.tokengeneration.saml2.statements.AuthnContextMapper.
You should configure mappings between SAML2 attribute names (Map keys) and local OpenAM attributes (Map values).
The DefaultAttributeMapper looks at profile attributes in configured data stores, or in session properties.
The map keys will define the names of the attributes included in Assertion Attribute statements.
The data pulled from the subject's directory entry or session state corresponding to the map value will define the value corresponding to the name of the attribute.
Map keys can be set up in the following format: [NameFormatURI]|SAML_ATTRIBUTE_NAME.
If the attribute value is enclosed in quotes, that quoted value will be included in the attribute without mapping. Binary attributes should be followed by ';binary'.
Beyond that, examples for appropriate mappings include:
If checked, this implementation of REST-STS will sign the assertion of the associated token.
Encrypt the entire assertion. If enabled, do not enable the Encrypt Attributes or Encrypt NameID options.
Encrypt the assertion Attributes. If enabled, do not enable the Encrypt Assertion option.
Encrypt the assertion NameID. If enabled, do not enable the Encrypt Assertion option.
Select the algorithm used to encrypt assertions.

REST-STS can use the same keystore that is used for OpenAM. While the version of Java that you use includes its own version of the keytool command, the location where you set up the keystore file may vary.
For example, you may use the procedure To Set Up OpenAM With HTTPS on Tomcat, if you use Tomcat as the container for OpenAM.

Set this to the location of the keystore file of your choice. For reference, the default OpenAM keystore file is keystore.jks, found in the OpenAM configuration directory, as described in the following installation procedure: To Deploy OpenAM
Enter the password for the keystore file, normally keystore.jks. The default password for that file packaged with OpenAM is changeit.
Re-enter the password for the keystore file to confirm.
Alias used for the encryption key; you may use that alias with the keytool command.
REST-STS uses a signature key to verify X.509 tokens. Enter the desired alias for that signature key.
Enter the password for the signature key.
Re-enter the password for the signature key to confirm.
